adjective.description: Consisting in or characterized by the presence or possession of features or qualities rather than their absence.

examples: there needs to be a positive approach to youthful offenders
adopt a positive outlook on life

adjective.description: With no possibility of doubt; clear and definite.
examples: he made a positive identification of a glossy ibis

adjective.description: Of, containing, producing, or denoting an electric charge opposite to that carried by electrons.
(of a photographic image) showing lights and shades or colors true to the original.
(of an adjective or adverb) expressing a quality in its basic, primary degree.
Dealing only with matters of fact and experience; not speculative or theoretical.
Relating to or denoting any of the air or fire signs, considered active in nature.

noun.description: A good, affirmative, or constructive quality or attribute.
examples: take your weaknesses and translate them into positives
to manage your way out of recession, accentuate the positive

noun.description: A photographic image showing lights and shades or colors true to the original, especially one printed from a negative.
A result of a test or experiment indicating the presence of something.
examples: let us look at the distribution of those positives

noun.description: The part of an electric circuit that is at a higher electrical potential than another point designated as having zero electrical potential.
An adjective or adverb in the positive degree.

origin: Late Middle English: from Old French positif, -ive or Latin positivus, from posit- placed, from the verb ponere. The original sense referred to laws as being formally laid down, which gave rise to the sense explicitly laid down and admitting no question, hence certain.
